items.name: Alice in Wonderland Statue
items.funFact: The Alice in Wonderland statue has been rubbed so much by visitors that parts of it shine brightly.

items.name: Cleopatra's Needle
items.funFact: Cleopatra's Needle is a 3,500-year-old Egyptian obelisk gifted to New York in 1881.

items.name: The Dakota Building View
items.funFact: The Dakota Building, visible from the park, is where John Lennon lived and was tragically shot in 1980.

items.name: Bethesda Terrace Arcade
items.funFact: The Bethesda Terrace Arcade features intricate Minton tile work and was restored in 2007.

items.name: Loeb Boathouse
items.funFact: Loeb Boathouse is the only restaurant in Central Park and offers gondola rides on the lake.

items.name: Ramble Bridge
items.funFact: The Ramble is a 38-acre wooded area with over 50 bridges and is a haven for birdwatchers.

items.name: Delacorte Theater
items.funFact: Delacorte Theater hosts Shakespeare in the Park, a free summer theater festival since 1962.

items.name: Bethesda Lake
items.funFact: Bethesda Lake is the second-largest body of water in Central Park and is home to various fish species.

items.name: Bow Bridge Arch
items.funFact: Bow Bridge's cast-iron arch is a marvel of 19th-century engineering and spans 87 feet.

items.name: The Obelisk
items.funFact: The Obelisk, also called Cleopatra's Needle, is one of only two Egyptian obelisks in the Western Hemisphere.

items.name: Greystone Bridge
items.funFact: Greystone Bridge is made of Manhattan schist and granite, the same rock that forms the park's foundation.

items.name: Mineral Springs
items.funFact: Mineral Springs was a popular gathering spot in the 19th century for its natural spring water.

items.name: Azalea Pond
items.funFact: Azalea Pond is surrounded by beautiful flowering plants and is a peaceful retreat in the park.

items.name: Pilgrim Hill
items.funFact: Pilgrim Hill offers one of the best views of the park and is named after the Pilgrims' journey.

items.name: Cedar Hill
items.funFact: Cedar Hill is home to a variety of cedar trees and offers scenic views of the park.

items.name: The Reservoir
items.funFact: The Reservoir is a 106-acre body of water that was once used as a water supply for the city.
